Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 03:32PM suzyq47 wrote: I ask myself everyday ...WHY .... I truly believe that God has a plan for everyone .. but how can it be possible for so many people, families, and lives to be torn apart by BC and for there to be a just answer. My sister just turned 50 on March 2, and then spent 13 days in the hospital recovering from the side effects of Xeloda, while we were hoping for a miracle that she could continue taking the very drug that made her so sick (because we knew it really works and could maybe prolong her life). My only thoughts are that it has to be the journey, the people you meet along the way, the lives you touch daily, even by simply posting, you have made a difference, you have people that love you, it's OK to cry, just don't give up ..............my thoughts are with you.
Posts.Title: 28 YR Old Is Looking For Support from You wwaterlilyy ibcmets

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 01:36PM suzyq47 wrote: It was terrfying to get a stage IV dx from the beginning especially becasue after the biopsy we thought we were dealing with stage II, but we went from Stage II to Stage IV in our intially onc visit and have felt that there hasn't been very much info out there for Stage IV....
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 10:48AM suzyq47 wrote: The only bio that was done has been on the main tumor when she was first dx in August. I ask onc about doing a liver bio also, he said it wasn't necessary at this time. The onc we went to for a second opinion had said the only difference in her treatment plan is that he would have done a liver bio, repeat tumor markers, and he pushes the limits on giving chemo at a lower rates when other Dr. wait for levels to recover. Our second opinion onc is at a research hospital in a bigger hospital where as our local onc is more cautious about lowering the counts to much. I take comfort in the fact that they are working together, since they have 2 different opinions, but still worry that an agressive cancer needs aggressive treatment. Our local onc is cautious about her physical and mental ability to handle the treatments since she is handicapped. I hope that the chemo works this time, it is scary to think of the outcome if her tumors continue to grow out of control for another 3 months.... praying for the best..and hoping for remission.. for everyone that this diease affects. I have two girls, so I worry that I may pass the BC gene onto to them, since my sister was dx before 50.
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 10:23AM - edited Apr 14, 2011 04:53PM by suzyq47 Did you wake up today and feel the need to make someone smile; make a difference in someone's life, to give happiness without needing anything in return? Then mail a card (Get Well, Thinking of You, any card) to Carol Collins 2684 Leading Creek Rd. Big Springs, West Virginia 26137. I promise that you will make someone very special smile and make her day a whole lot brighter!
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: suzyq47 wrote: My 49 year old mentally handicapped sister was dx on 8-18-2010 with breast cancer, bio and scans showed Stage IV,Poorly differentrated infiltrated ductal carnemia, agressive, 4cm massive, with mets to nodes, liver, lungs, ER+/ HER2 neg, pre-meno. Onc started her on Taxol and Avastin on 9-14-2010. She just completed her first cycle and had repeat PET SCAN on Dec. 7, 2010 and are waiting on results to see if protocal is working. We are so scared! She is a child trapped in an adult body, but doing very well on treatment so far. Only side effects are hair loss. We have her taking Prilisec daily and drinking 64 oz of water and gatorade daily. She had had good labs so far after 9 treatments,holding our breath, still using veins and haven't had to put a port in yet, my question is if she responds to meds, whats next? She hasn't had any surgeries or rad or hormone therphy. She lives and hr away with my oldest brother, 82 year old dad, and mom  who has dementia. So when she gets her treatments and appointments I take her and she usually stays with us for 3-4 days so I am trying to research and make sure we are doing what we have to do and know what to do to take care of her... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 12:15AM suzyq47 wrote: My sister has had 4 Ixempre infusions and started her 3rd set of  Xeloda ( finished 8 days of the 14 day dose), but has the hand syndrome (feet are ok so far), but we didn't know to make sure she didn't rub her hands, we should have had her blot the lotions and Vaseline on heavy since the rubbing and friction makes the capillaries in her hands release the chemo. We started using Bag Balm (and it has helped her hands alot, they don't hurt, but they looked like they have been scalded and the skin peeled off). Our biggest concern now is diarrhea and vomiting even with compazine and anti-diarr meds so we tried Zofran today, for 2 doses, but she almost fainted and was shivering.So we held her PM dose of Xeloda and will take her to see ONC tomorrow, we hope he stops for a couple days and then lowers the dose, she weighs about 115 so we are  hoping if they lower the dose she can still take it. We really want her to continue on this if possible. She has done great on Ixempra no SE, Xeloda was going really well until starting the 3rd set of 14 day treatment. Her hair has even grown back and is about 1/2 long now. Today was her 50th birthday, even though she couldn't enjoy her ice cream cake or eat anything, she had a great day. Hopefully tomorrow the onc can come up with a plan to save her treatment of Xeloda. She does have to have a port put in and time to heal before her next chemo infusion on March 16, so we hope things improve and she can get good news on her PET Scan after 2 more Ixempra infusions. God Bless you, keep fighting, thank you for always being there !!! You are all amazing people!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 01:50PM suzyq47 wrote: I can now speak for the adverse side effects of Xeloda. My sister had her 4th Ixempra infusion on 2-23-11, and we started Xeloda for her 3rd round of 3000 mg a day, but only finished 8 days out of 14. The diarr, vomiting, and hand and foot syndrome were to much, by 3-3-11 she was admitted to the hospital for severe dehydration; low counts, low bp; nausea and vomiting. We endured a 13 day stay before she was released, I had to stay with her 24/7 because she had to have someone sitting by her side the whole time, except for 2 nights when my sister in law stayed with her. At one point she had 19 bouts of diarr in 1 day ..next day was 9.... it took alot of meds and trial and error to control all the medical issues.  It was surreal to see how bad and how long it took for her to recover from Xeloda side effects.We were really hoping she could take it and let it do it's magic, but it was to much for her. She did receive the Sub Q Port while she was an inpatient, since her veins where blowing in her right hand and her left hand was still trying to recover from Ixempra chemo burn! So the last month has sucked for her !!! I know Xeloda is a great chemo drug, and really wish she could have continued on it, but due to many factors, the side effects got out of control very quickly. So I hope that by posting our experience, Xeloda users will make sure, they call their Onc, as soon as diarr or vomiting occurs, and stop taking Xeloda until side effects go away, we tried to treat the side effects and continue Xeloda .... that didn't work for my sister... hind sight ...we should stopped Xeloda as soon as she was throwing up and had diarr at the same time, and I also recommend Ativan (for nasuea ) and to never take compazine which caused major hand tremors that lasted for days !!!!!  Now we have to face a PET Scan in a couple months and are praying that the hell she went threw from Xeloda at least helped her mets and Onc will have to come up with another drug to use???
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 04:58PM suzyq47 wrote:  Carol got good news today on her PET Scan results today. There are " no" new tumors; main BC tumor has decreased in size and activity;sternum lesion has decreased in activity; left lung nodule has decreased in size and no signs of activity, lymph nodes are doing better; tumor in left lobe of the liver is still there, but decreased in activity and shows dead tissue from the chemo working, so she will have next Ixempra next Monday. Its not perfect, but we will take it, she has been off treatment since she was in the hospital from Xeloda side effects ..... Chemo and prays are working, we can't give up !!
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 10:46PM suzyq47 wrote: Hello, I am so sorry that you and your wife have gone through so much and just wanted to let you know that I admire your grit for hanging tough to make sure the Onc doesn't make mistakes. Fighting BC is bad enough let alone the nightmare of protecting her from medical mistakes as well. I agree with the other post that suggest you try and find a new local onc and have the long distance onc consult on treatments. I have a handicapped sister that is being treated in a small cancer center (that only has 2 cancer Dr.'s) but we took her to WVU Hospital in Morgantown (2 hours away) and met with the top cancer onc there and  the onc consult on her case by phone. We are fortunate that my sisters local onc is excellent, but we still needed that second opinion.  Best wishes to you both, I pray that you find a new Onc that you can trust and a treatment that works with great success!
Posts.Title: Hello all, and advice needed NancysHubby NancysHubby

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 01:28PM suzyq47 wrote: Pet Scan report showed the main tumor in the breast has decreased in size and intensity of metabolic activity and the lung nodule has decreased in size and activity also. But the liver has increased to 11 cm (which onc is consulting with radiologist to see if it could be dead tissue from chemo killing off the many spots that she had before or a growing mass) and the left hilar areas of the lymph nodes are bigger and now a lytic lesion involving the sternum. So she has seen some important, but some areas are a lot worse. So the onc is reviewing with her consultant physician to determine which chemo drugs to try next. So they sent us home today, and we wait until next Tuesday to start a new drug therapy. My sister's breast cancer dx of stage IV is a result of not doing routine mammograms. We can kick ourselves over and over, but we are another statistic proving the need for yearly exams. She looks an acts perfectly healthily, but has so much going on inside. So now we wait a week for a new plan and pray that this plan works on all the tumors.
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 11:00AM suzyq47 wrote: Tuesday my sister starts Ixempra (Ixabepilone) once every 3 weeks .... so praying this one works.. 11 cm liver mass in just 3 months ... we are hoping she doesn't have several SEs?? Read the info. so hoping she handles it ok...
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 09:11PM suzyq47 wrote: My sister had her first dose of 60 mg of Ixempra on Tuesday, Dec 21, 2010, her protocol is once every 3 weeks. She had 1 hr of premeds and 3 hr infusion of chemo, and so far the only side effects that she seems to have is to be a little tired, but says she feels fine. I don't want to say it to loudly, but we are hoping for the best. She will have follow up blood work and Dr. check this coming Tuesday, so hopefully she continues to do well. We are praying that this one works. Merry Christmas to you all and I hope the New year finds you all in good health!
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 07:55PM suzyq47 wrote: My sister starts Xeloda 3000mg (split into 2 doses ) a day for 14 days then off for 7 to work with the Ixempra (60mg) once every 3 weeks. Her onc gave 2 Ixempra treatments to see how she would tolerate them, then today added the Xeloda, which had to be ordered and can't get until tomorrow. But he said to watch for side effects of the mouth, stomach, and intestinal tract, and the hands and feet. My sister started with Taxol and Avestin - but her scattered spots in the liver grow into a 11 CM mass along with other mets progressions - so he jumped up to this protocol. I hope her luck continues, but so far she has felt wonderful, a little tired, but has had no complaints since starting chemo in Sept. 2010. I honestly hope that all of you have great success with your treatments ..... and I would like to see everyone find a way to beat this monster ....best wishes..
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:20PM suzyq47 wrote: My sister is tolerating Ixempra really well, Onc added Zeloda (3000 mg a day for 14 days) on Jan.12 and she gets a 7 days break before next Ixempra infusion and another round of of Zeloda. So far she seems to be doing really well.. except she has had a copy dizzy spills, where her bp was dropping when she stood up about 3 times the first few days of her last chemo, so Onc wants a MRI of the brain. So please pray that it hasn't spread to her brain. She was only dizzy those three times and has been fine since. Levels are down a little, so hoping the brain is fine and chemo is zapping the crap out of her cancer ..........
Posts.Title: Stage IV, suzyq47 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 04:54PM suzyq47 wrote: She is able to tell us if and where she hurts, and we ask her constantly to make sure her fingers and toes aren't tingly or to make sure nothing feels weird or anything. How do we gain hope if we have to relay on meds alone, even if it shrinks or stops growing, it sounds like it will either stop responding or return with a vengeance. She had a mammo done 8-18-2010 which dx the mass, PET Scan (showed nodes, liver, and lungs) and MRI of brain was clear in Sept. 2010, and  repeated PET Scan Dec. 7, 2010. If it responds to the chemo now, removing the main mass seems like a logical step? So they never do surgery for Stage IV? Thank you for your input we do greatly appreciate it. Just feeling a little lost.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 10:28PM suzyq47 wrote: My sister had her Onc follow up today-- MRI Brain Scan was clear !!!!!  So dizziness maybe from low counts and dropping bp when she stands up to fast. Today was day 14 on Xeloda, since her counts are down he said skip the last evening dose this evening. Onc started her on antibiotic because of  WBC is down as a precaution, but my sister says that she still feels really good, except she is tired. We thank God for that blessing. My sister is HER2 neg., and Estrogen receptor pos, I may have posted those wrong in the beginning-- if I did I will try to correct them. I really hope and pray that you ladies stay strong and live well, I pray for all of my sisters on here! God bless you all.
